first: ^CT: A box of bleached card-stock emblazoned in orange with a drawing of seven pointed leaf--

^X: It's a good miniature of the original piece, and the ink is holding up fine.

^Enough, just check the cards for smudging.

^X: Just like the last deck you checked.
last: ^CT: Another card box with an orange printed Gold-leaf.
^X: Again, the ink on this one smudged.
^X: And again, the cards inside are fine, with the exception of the orange suit, the Kings, which are heavily smudged.
^X: You're looking at the face of King Lav turning to mist.

c-0: ^X: The shape of things to come.
c-1: ^X: If the universe sent signs, they'd be subtler than this.

first: ^X: Like something out of long lost golden age. An age before irony.

first: ^CL: Something about that term strikes you as familiar: 'carbide lamp.'
^X: A vague memory of a steep auditorium, oak-panelled and chalky--something from your student days at the Academy.
second: ^X: You remember Vostok of Flocks, a steely-eyed young raven in your chemistry class, ranting against the 'purely theoretical' bend of the Academy."
^X: "Where's the application?" You can hear him croaking, "Where's the entrepreneurship? Why is the King paying to have our heads crammed with all these things if we're not to use them?"
^X: "Take calcium carbide for instance. . ." That was about the moment you'd started to zone out.
last: ^CL: Carbide lamps were not the only application of the sciences young Vostok had in mind--he wasn't all chemistry all the time.
^X: There was his fondness for psychometry too--the nascent ideas of Fran of Olds: the quantification of intelligence and temperament.
^X: The predictive models of personal accomplishment and of criminality; how to know who will be useful and who will be a menace.
^X: This was the thing that really animated Vostok: a scientific approach to meritocracy.

s: ^Eventually we will quantify everything, so why not the psyche?
^Some things are irreducible. There are questions the sciences cannot answer.
^I don't know what to think about that.

intro1: ^P: A slim book on Doc's desk lies open to a heading titled "Trouble Breathing, Trouble Speaking."
^X: Three subheadings have been lightly underlined with charcoal: 'Altmann's Disjunction,' 'Gastric stasis,' and 'Oesophageal Petrification.'.

s: ^"Hey, Doc, did you underline these for me?"

c-0: ^D: "I narrowed the possible conditions down a tad, yes--hope you don't mind."

s: ^"Actually, Doc, I was hoping you wouldn't hand-hold me."

c-0: ^D: "Maybe you were hoping for a challenge, but we're on a bit of a schedule, see?"
c-1: ^D: "Forgive me, old boy. Consider my help a 'tutorial' of sorts."

c-3: ^X: The intro is in verse, and oh-so-very terse:
^X: "If your patient cannot speak / you won't know what's wrong / and if they cannot breathe / they've not got long."

conditionsList: ^X: As the chapter title suggests, all three conditions cause difficulty in breathing and speaking, but they can be distinguished by other features.

g-0: ^X: "Altmann's disjunction is a condition of the nerves that causes the fine musculature of the upper body to fall out of sync with itself: the mouth doesn't know what the vocal cords are doing, the vocal cords don't know what the lungs are up to--ditto with the patient's left and right eyes."

s: ^"Wait, how would I recognize this on a patient?"
^Make a note of it and read on.

c-2: ^X: Look for a stilted chopped-up speech pattern and crossed eyes.

g-1: ^X: "Gastric stasis seizes up the core muscles of the mid-torso--locking up the diaphragm and pushing against the spinal cord causing a spike in cerebrospinal fluid pressure. The spike in pressure--it is hypothesized--is what causes the tell-tale delusions and hallucinations."

s: ^"Hold on, how would this stand out during diagnosis?"
^Note it and check the last entry.

c-4: ^X: You're looking for delusional rabbits with cramped abs.

g-2: ^X: "Oesophageal petrification puts the oesophagus into a kind of dessicated stupor, drying out the mouth and making speaking over a whisper an ordeal--like falling asleep on your arm and losing feeling in it, but it's not your arm--its your throat."

s: ^"So, what should I look out for?"

c-6: ^X: A dry mouth speaking in a barely audible whisper.

bottom: ^X: You finish your notes on the possible conditions, it's time to check up on Batesie--see if anything matches up.

s: ^Wait, check something else in the book.

^X: His heart-rate is a spot under 300 beats per minute.

^X: Occasionally, airborne coal dust in closed spaces will combust explosively without warning--and in the absence of open flames.
^X: What causes this is a mystery, but mining operations take measures to prevent the build-up of coal dust in the air.
^X: Carbide is a a broad term for a compound of carbon and metals. What you're looking for is calcium carbide--an off-white powder that reacts to water.
^X: Water dripping on calcium carbide produces acetylene gas, which burns with a warm steady light.
^X: Calcium carbide can be toxic if ingested, but the acetylene gas is safe.
^X: According to the Industrial Uses section: "Calcium carbide head lamps have been used extensively in mining operation across the Kingdom since their introduction in 1845."--i.e. three years ago.

knot_burrows_ending: ^X: As you made your way to Pride to meet the King, the actions you took that day reverberated throughout Burrows and beyond.

b: ^ X: With your help, Quince managed to repair the engine in what was found to be record time--fully solidifying his position as apprentice engineer; perhaps the first Vermin to ever be honoured in that way.
^ X: Following your admission of guilt in the matter of the steam engine, Quince continued to work as Bates' apprentice largely safe from Aldwyn's unwelcome attention.

^ X: Bates' expertise and reputation largely shielded him from the weight the accusations you levied against him to Aldwyn, but Bates did not take kindly to such aspersions. He has not written to you since you left.
^ X: After you left As Aldwyn promised, Quince was removed from the position of apprentice engineer, despite Bates' protestations.
^ X: Not three weeks later, with the spirits still high from the successful strike, Rowan was fired from his job. The official reason was 'downsizing,' but the message from the Company was clear:
^ X: 'We have eyes and ears everywhere and you won't get away with this.'

^ X: Spurred by the success of his campaign, Rowan became convinced in the power of political activism, and dedicated himself to bettering the station of Rabbits and other Commoners in Animal Kingdom.
^ X: Your research into the cause of the outbreak allowed Doc Hopper to resolve it in a matter of days.
^ X: Within a day or two, as Bates' health worsened, it was clear that your proposed source of the outbreak wasn't correct.
^ X: Despite the Doc's best efforts the illness spread throughout the rabbit population in the Burrows, the drop in available workforce caused the mining operation to grind to a halt.
^ X: As a consequence over half of the miners were left without a job in the following downsizing.
^ X: With the strike broken, Rowan and Inigo have found themselves disillusioned with their fellow rabbits and coworkers.
^ X: They've given up on political activism.
^ X: As Rowan and Inigo expected, Rowan was fired not three weeks later.
^ X: Spurred by the injustice Rowan left Burrows, and made his way to Pride in search of a fabled den of political agitators.

^ X: In the following months, Rowan of Burrows, armed with steely conviction, has made a name for himself among the nascent Revolutionary movement--he is still thankful to you for doing the right thing.

knot_burrows_charlesPainting: ^CHARLES_PNTNG: It's a self-portrait of you, Charles!
knot_burrows_billboard: ^BI: A few notices hang from the dusty cork-board. Do you want to read any?

s: ^'Are Your Children safe? A note on Revolutionaries.'

c-0: ^X: It's an ad for a sale at Jeffrey's Depot, he's giving 50% off on card-stock and poles.
c-1: ^X: A printed notice has been been scrawled over with profanities to the point of illegibility.
^X: Seems you won't be finding out if 'your children' are safe.
c-2: ^X: "Need help clearing out old junk in front of flat, need 2-3 hardy rabbits, good pay."
c-3: ^X: A rambling, meandering, utterly confusing pamphlet.
^X: The basic thrust is that carrots are getting less crunchy and that this is a sign of some kind of anti-rabbit conspiracy?
^X: And something about making rabbits 'sick' by forcing them to eat 'foreign foods'?

s: ^Blazes, this pamphlet was right! The rabbits did get sick from eating foreign food!"

c-0: ^X: Maybe it's also right about the carrots getting less crunchy?

s: ^Let's not get ahead of ourselves here.

knot_burrows_hay: ^X: Looking at the hay piled in the corner of the forge, it occurs to you that someone has been sleeping here.

b: ^ X: This is probably where Quince sleeps.

knot_burrows_forge: ^X: A brazier has been left unattended, but its still glowing hot enough to singe hair.
^X: Coal really keeps a fine heat.
knot_burrows_anvil: ^X: A massive anvil and a massive hammer to match. It must've taken a dozen rabbits to move it into place.
^X: It's hard to imagine a rabbit swinging the hammer. . .
